.T: Reducing renal injury during transplantation [see comments]

When the kidney is removed from cold storage for implantation into the recipient it gradually rewarms (second warm ischaemic time) and a prolonged second warm ischaemic time has been shown to be a cause of acute tubular necrosis following transplantation. The temperature rise in a kidney during implantation has been poorly investigated and little work to minimize that rise has been carried out. This study investigates, in an animal model, the changes that occur in the core temperature of kidneys during the second warm ischaemic time. Maintaining a low kidney core temperature during the second warm ischaemic time will reduce injury to the kidney and should be part of routine clinical practice.
